text:
We have so much fun on the @@4232652 Bicibús, biking to school with a group of kids

Interested in starting one for your school for Earth Day (April 22) or Bike to School Day (May 8)?

Join the monthly SSAFETY & WABA bike bus chat on Zoom! Next Tues 3/12 at 8p 

Details: ssafety.org/bike-bus/

We had a great Bicibús to Escuela Key yesterday. It was cold, we had some challenges, but we all kept riding, we all made it to school, and the kids arrived with a huge sense of accomplishment and ready to win Friday!

Or maybe that was just me. Happy Weekend!

My major take aways:

The good: no cars

Needs improvement: - too narrow
- not enough warning for blind corners & exits/entrances
- figuring out where you are on the trail and where various exits lead to is overly difficult

🚨Virginia Action Alert 1/2🚨

Two street safety bills this week:

1) Expand automated speed enforcement/cameras Generally: HB20, HB521, HB533, HB905, HB1072; Bigger school zones: HB21

Submit comments: hodspeak.house.virginia.gov/submit_testi...
My comments: gmb-comments.blogspot.com/2024/01/supp...

Great news! The bike bus bill passed unanimously out of subcommittee!

This means it *should* go on the consent agenda (i.e. the package of bills with no opposition) to be voted out of the House. Next stop will be the Senate!

I'll update the group when I know more. Thanks to everyone who wrote in!
Thank you!
Thanks!

🚨Action Alert!🚨

The Va legislature is considering SUPPORT for ACTIVE STUDENT TRANSPORTATION!!!

You can help support HB937 by:
1. Click hodspeak.house.virginia.gov/committees/H... , scroll to HB937 & leave written comment

2.  Use this form: mstr.app/4fb645a1-3a0... to send an email

Please share!

It's (finally) happening! Arlington Kids can ride any transit bus in Arlington for FREE - both ART and WMATA! 

Kids need an iRide card, which they can get for free through their schools or at a Commuter Store (at the store, you can show ParventVue or school ID)

www.arlingtonva.us/About-Arling...

You can again order cookies for shipped or girl delivery from your favorite cycling Girl Scout

She'll deliver in North Arlington, east of George Mason or arrange pick up near Cherrydale

 Until we run out or March 10

www.gsdigitalcookie.com/cookie/Landi...

Do you live north of Roanoke & ride bikes with kids? We need you!

But seriously, looking for family bike folks who live in Virginia's 37th House District (map below). DM me!  Thanks!!

Great news! You can still order cookies for girl delivery* today (Sunday).

She'll deliver in North Arlington, east of George Mason or arrange pick up near Cherrydale

You can also order for direct shipping or donations until March 10

www.gsdigitalcookie.com/cookie/Landi...

#Bikedc & DMV friends! Your favorite 7-mile-to-school bike commuting Girl Scout  is still selling girl scout cookies. 

If you order <TONIGHT> you can save on shipping and receive scout-delivered cookies right to your doorstep* early February.  www.gsdigitalcookie.com/cookie/Landi...

🚨Stolen bike alert🚨

My super awesome niece, who bikes to school every day in the windy city, returned from family Xmas to find her beautiful maroon Haro Brisa ebike stolen without its battery.

Pls keep an eye out!

Santa is ready tomorrow's ride.

RSVP & Deets: fb.me/e/KQlmOvrK
Nope. A little rain doesn't stop Santa

Awesome ride this morning! Thanks to all who came out!

Also, it was 30-something degrees when we started the ride. Kids were so happy to be riding and many took off layers as we rode. Weather doesn't stop the #bikebus joy!
I have a cat pic for you, friend
Camera traffic enforcement can be about changing behavior and not about raising funds. It just has to be well implemented

Actually, I chair the public commission that oversees our county budget. We take in very little in traffic fines and the funds we do bring in go to the general fund, not directly to police.

Studies show that most people only get one ticket from a camera - so we're discussing implementation options
I'm not sure who needs to see this but please enjoy our Christmas Cats
Have a great holiday season.
But I am sorry whenever I see Americans that are so disillusioned with our democracy that they see no path forward to making government work with appropriate restrictions. It really does make me sad.

Oh, the old "I'm taking my ball and going home" post.  And here I was thinking this site was more about civil dialogue than the other one.  

Thanks for disabusing me of that notion!

Regulation is written by government - it's not what restricts government.

Legislation is what restricts the reach of the executive branch. The Constitution restricts the actions of the entire government.

I could mirror your tone and say "like, you get people are dying, right?" But that's not helpful to civil discourse. 

I think we fundamentally disagree on the possibility of effectively limiting government. Ok. Hope you're having a lovely holiday season

There are various issues to weigh here - the need for people to get around, the social justice of our land use and transportation systems.  It's not an easy issue. I think government can be constrained and used for good.
Oh, you must have missed the posts where I said I support limits on the police use of this information (which we have in Virginia) and prefer camera systems to be run by DOTs and not police.

Sorry you feel that way. We do in fact fundamentally disagree.

I think human life is valuable and worth figuring out how to allow government collection of information about behavior while applying appropriately limits to ensure government power isn't abused.

That is an absolutely awesome long term goal (though I wouldn't use China as an example of safe transportation systems or of data protections)

Serious improvements in transit & infrastructure take time. So in the interim, how do we reduce traffic violence?
But I guess you disagree with that and ok living with the amount of traffic violence out there today, at least until we can improve infrastructure & transit, which is unfortunate

It seems cameras, separated from police and with data protections, could be a tool that can start reducing traffic deaths more quickly than infrastructure improvements can be implemented. So let's figure out a way to have cameras in a just way & continue to work towards more transit & better infra

I've actually read a lot on the topic. If you've read the threads you'll see my main point is that it's important to end traffic violence in a non racist way, and that we have to work through the complicated issues involved in race and enforcement to do so
So how would you address traffic violence?

Would I talk about how to end traffic violence with non white people? Yes, I do it all the time. Without involving everyone, we can't get to just solutions.

Even the OP (eventually) admitted that she could support cameras with restrictions.
If you read the thread, you'll see that this is not at all what I'm saying

Because I think we need to think hard about how the decrease traffic violence?

Okkkkkkk
Oh, wait, what's my solution? I keep saying we need to have a discussion to come to one that addresses all the issues.

I could absolutely get on board with restrictions along those lines.

Btw, the reason implementation has been delayed in at least some Virginia jurisdictions is this very discussion about how to implement justly.

I don't actually but you really want to put words in my mouth. Both are problems.

Fixing infrastructure only goes so far and will take significant time. People are dying now.

I support solutions that both work to end traffic violence and don't perpetuate the police state.
Btw, having a loved one killed also worsens poverty.
So would you be in favor of cameras run by the DOT (like in DC post reform, but with more data protections)?

That's not what I said. But anyone who would like to can read the thread. 

I could flip it around and say you're ok with Black & brown kids being killed - but I actually don't think that's what you said either 

Instead of shouting people down online, how about working towards actual solutions?
So instead of shouting people down online, how about discussing what the concerns are & finding solutions?

Again, I think it's far more complicated than "these can never work"

I take it you're also not ok with a system that disproportionately kills or seriously injures Black & brown people? Cause that's the system we have now.
As a lawyer, you certainly know that a lien can lead to seizure of an asset in some circumstances. But not incarceration

Automated enforcement saves lives - disproportionately lives of people of color. Seems like the most anti-racist stance would be to support anti-racist implementation of cameras, not oppose them outright

As a lawyer, you certainly know that different states often have different laws on the same subject. You've pointed to some states that have problematic implementation of speed cameras. Fair enough.

But other states have different implementation that seem to address your concerns.

Again, this all started with someone from Virginia advocating for the Virginia version of cameras. I guarantee you there are not thousands of Virginians incarcerated for speed camera violations - the law doesn't allow that.
So am I. I haven't read every law in every state & your comments made me think you were not familiar with it.
I believe it can become a lien on the car. The behavior can't be attributed to an individual
Also, seems odd to staunchly oppose something that doesn't have a track record. Have you read up on th Virginia law and its limitations?

Given the data showing that cameras reduce traffic violence & that traffic violence hits the most vulnerable communities in the US the hardest, wouldn't the better play be to advocate for cameras, but a system separated from the police?
Oh, and Virginia's law is fine-only. It doesn't integrate with the carceral state, as you say.
So you can put cameras in other areas, but that more traffic violence in places where poc live. It's not a simple problem - and discussion of it is not well geared to a character limited platform

On the race issue, there's an intersectionality here that makes it complicated: areas with more people of color tend to see more traffic violence, and automated enforcement is a quick way to reduce traffic violence, but tends to capture violations from nearby residents more, particularly at the 1st
I did. I agree that the storage of data is a huge issue, but Virginia's law seems to have good protections (it hasn't been around very long so not a lot of track record)
No, not everywhere in the US. Sounds like your issue is with collection of data, not automated enforcement per se
Ah, the changing of the seasons

3) retail distributed throughout

4) height near metro

Can we start every community meeting with this great quote? 

But fighting a change just because you don’t like it personally, without regard for what your resistance means for others, is a quick way to become an unsympathetic character in your own story

Spectacular start to the school year for the Escuela Key Bicibús!  We have a new route & a great return for our og route!  Thanks to all who came out!
Happy first day of school to Arlington Public Schools, especially to all who walked, biked or took transit (including the school bus!) To school!

APS Transportation has been eliminating hub stops (bus stops for option schools). If you're troubled by this development, please sign on to this letter: docs.google.com/document/d/1... Feel free to pass along to others who might be interested (especially at other option schools).
Hi, y'all 👋
